Journal.Title: Chemphyschem : a European journal of chemical physics and physical chemistry

Article.ArticleTitle: Assessing the Viability of the Methylsulfinyl Radical-Ozone Reaction.

AbstractText: Although integral to remote marine atmospheric sulfur chemistry, the reaction between methylsulfinyl radical (CH<sub>3</sub> SO) and ozone poses challenges to theoretical treatments. The lone theoretical study on this reaction reported an unphysically large barrier of 66 kcal mol<sup>-1</sup> for abstraction of an oxygen atom from O<sub>3</sub> by CH<sub>3</sub> SO. Herein, we demonstrate that this result stems from improper use of MP2 with a single-reference, unrestricted Hartree-Fock (UHF) wavefunction. We characterized the potential energy surface using density functional theory (DFT), as well as multireference methodologies employing a complete active-space self-consistent field (CASSCF) reference. Our DFT PES shows, in contrast to previous work, that the reaction proceeds by forming an addition adduct [CH<sub>3</sub> S(O<sub>3</sub> )O] in a deep potential well of 37 kcal mol<sup>-1</sup> . An O-O bond of this adduct dissociates via a flat, low barrier of 1 kcal mol<sup>-1</sup> to give CH<sub>3</sub> SO<sub>2</sub> +O<sub>2</sub> . The multireference computations show that the initial addition of CH<sub>3</sub> SO+O<sub>3</sub> is barrierless. These results provide a more physically intuitive and accurate picture of this reaction than the previous theoretical study. In addition, our results imply that the CH<sub>3</sub> SO<sub>2</sub> formed in this reaction can readily decompose to give SO<sub>2</sub> as a major product, in alignment with the literature on CH<sub>3</sub> SO reactions.
